title: Game Theory Breakthrough: Two-Player Games Are Always Zero-Sum!
summary: A groundbreaking new study has resolved a longstanding conjecture in game theory, proving that all two-player adversarial games are zero-sum.
intro: Get ready for an exciting leap forward in game theory, the mathematical study of strategic interactions! Researchers have just proven a long-sought result: all two-player adversarial games are strategically zero-sum. This discovery unifies diverse areas of game theory and computer science, opening up new possibilities for research and applications.
text:
Two-person adversarial games are those in which each player's gain is another player's loss. The Luce-Raiffa-Aumann (LRA) conjecture questioned whether these games could ever be nonzero-sum, meaning that a win for one player doesn't necessarily mean a loss for the other.

In their recent letter, researchers have finally put this question to rest by proving that two-player adversarial games are indeed strategically zero-sum. They achieved this by unifying and simplifying existing proofs by Adler-Daskalakis-Papadimitriou (2009) and Raimondo (2023).

This breakthrough resolves a longstanding debate in game theory, as previous findings hinted that certain two-player adversarial games might be nonzero-sum. The new proof clarifies these ambiguities, strengthening the foundations of game theory as a whole.

Moreover, this study establishes connections with earlier work on strategically zero-sum games by Moulin and Vial (1978) and on axiomatizations of multi-linear utilities of n-person games by Fishburn and Roberts (1976, 1978). These links bring together two seemingly disparate communities under the umbrella of adversarial games.

This reorientation is particularly significant as it highlights the relevance of two-person zero-sum games, which have been studied extensively by Aumann (1961), Shapley (1964), and Rosenthal (1974). It also emphasizes recent algorithmic advances in computer science, providing a fresh perspective on this fascinating field.

With these developments, game theorists can now focus their efforts on exploring new areas of research and applications, confident that the fundamental principles of two-player adversarial games are firmly established.
